article:
John Aubrey, Memoires of Naturall Remarques in the County of Wilts, Royal Society MS 92, 221 (hereafter RS MS 92) recommendations of Michael Hunter as described in "How to Edit a Seventeenth-Century Manuscript: Principles and Practice,” Seventeenth Century 10 (1995): 277-310
[Michael Hunter ?] Editing Early Modern Texts: An Introduction to Principles and Practice (Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan, 2007).
John Aubrey, The Naturall Historie of Wiltshire (Bodleian Library,MS Aubrey 1 , 2).
Ernst Gerhardt, “'No Quyckar Merchandyce than Library Bokes': John Bale's Commodification of Manuscript Culture," Renaissance Quarterly 60 (2007):421-22. Adam Fox, "Custom, Memory and the Authority of Writing," in The Experience of Authority in Early Modern England, ed. Paul Griffiths, Adam Fox, and Steve Hindle (New York: St. Martin’s Press, 1996), 89-116
Jan Broadway, “No Historie So Meete”: Gentry and Culture and the Development of Local History in Elizabethan and Early Stuart England (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 2006), 121-26. Ian Gadd and Alexandra Gillespie, eds., John Stow (1525-1605) and the Making of the English Past (London: British Library, 2004) in particular Gillespie, “Stow’s ‘Owlde’ Manuscripts of London Chronicles,” 57-67. C.E. Wright, “The Dispersal of the Libraries in the Sixteenth Century,” in The English Library Before 1700: Studies in Its History, ed. Francis Wormald and C.E. Wright (London: University of London, the Athlone Press, 1958), 156-57, 170. C.J. Wright, ed., Sire Robert Cotton as Collector: Essays on an Early Stuart Collector and His Legacy (London: British Library, 1997). Margaret Aston, "English Ruins and English History: The Dissolution and the Sense of the Past," Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes 36 (1973):231-55 Michael Hunter, John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning (New York: Science History Publications, 1975), 191-202 Lorraine Daston, “Marvelous Facts and Miraculous Evidence in Early Modern Europe,” Critical Inquiry 18 (1991): 93-124 Stephan Clucas, “In Search of ‘The True Logick’: Methodological Eclecticism Among the ‘Baconian Reformers,’” in Samuel Hartlib and Universal Reformation: Studies in Intellectual Communication, ed. Mark Greengrass, Michael Leslie, and Timothy Raylor (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1994), 51-74 [Lorraine] Daston and Katharine Park, Wonders and the Order of Nature, 1150-1750 (New York: Zone Books, 1998), especially “Strange Facts,” 215-53 Barbara Shapiro, A Culture of Fact: England, 1550-1720 (Cornell: Cornell University Press, 2000), 63-85 and 105-38 William T. Lynch, Solomon’s Child: Method in the Early Royal Society of London (Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001), 1-33. Lesley B. Cormack, “‘Good Fences Make Good Neighbors’: Geography as Self-Definition in Early Modern England,” Isis 82 (1991): 639-61 (quote 656) [Deborah] Harkness, The Jewel House: Elizabethan London and the Scientific Revolution [New Haven: Yale University Press, 2007], 214-16, 241-53 Cormack, “‘Good Fences Make Good Neighbors,’” 658-60 Ann Blair, "Humanist Methods in Natural Philosophy: The Commonplace Book," Journal of the History of Ideas 53 (1992): 541-51. Michael Hunter, introduction to Archives of the Scientific Revolution: The Formation and Exchange of Ideas in Seventeenth Century Europe, ed. Michael Hunter (Woodbridge: Boydell Press, 1998), 6-11. Aubrey also regarded this as a viable option for certain kinds of works (Hunter, John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning, 66-67). Hunter, introduction, 11 [John] Evelyn, Memoires for my Grandson, British Library MS ADD 78515, 32r Frances Harris, Transformations of Love: The Friendship of John Evelyn and Margaret Godolphin (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2003), 42 and in passim. Robert Hooke, The Diary of Robert Hooke, MA, MD, FRS, 1672-1680, ed. Henry W. Robinson and Walter Adams (London: Taylor and Francis, 1935), entries of 21 September 1677, 314; 19 November 1677, 329; 28 November 1677, 330; 26 December 1677, 336; 28 December 1677, 337; 31 December 1677, 337-38; 1 January 1677/78, 338; 4 January 1677/78, 338; 12 January 1 677/78, 340. Edward Lhwyd, “Parochial Queries" (Oxford, 1696), Bod MS Ashmole 1820, 74v. At least three of the forty-four queries returned to Lhwyd have substantive answers to this question (MS Ashmole 1820, 121v, 133v, 143r) [John] Evelyn "Of Manuscripts: An Unfinished Treatise," in Memoirs Illustrative of the Life and Writings of John Evelyn, Esq. FRS, ed. William Bray (London: Henry Colburn, Conduit Street, 1818), 2.1:333-48. The manuscript copy of the treatise is no longer extant Evelyn, "Of Manuscripts," 339-48 Aubrey, RS MS 92, 221 Harold Love, The Culture and Commerce of Texts: Scribal Publication in Seventeenth-Century England (Amherst: University of Massachusetts Press, 1998) Aubrey to Anthony a Wood, {11 March 1690}, Bod MS Wood F.39, 400r Aubrey to Wood, 24 April 1690, Bod MS Wood F.39, 403r; Aubrey to Wood, 5 July 1690 and 10 July 1690, Bod MS Wood F.39, 405v Aubrey to Wood, 24 April 1690, Bod MS Wood F.39, 402r-403r Lhwyd to Aubrey, 2 March 1692/3, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 241r Aubrey to Wood, 24 April 1690, Bod MS Wood F.39, 403r Aubrey to Wood, 5 July 1690, Bod MS Wood F.39, 405v Lhwyd to Aubrey, 3 April {1693}, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 243r Lhwyd to Aubrey, 16 November 1693, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 250r Lhwyd to Aubrey, 9 January 1693/94, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 251r Lhwyd to Aubrey, 29 May 1694, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 257r Lhwyd to Aubrey, 44, March 1693/4, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 252r Lhwyd to Aubrey, 27 February 1693/94, Bod MS Aubrey 12, 260r Aubrey to Wood, 5 July 1690, Bod MS Wood F.39, 405v Hunter, John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning, 75-92. (Hunter, 79, 80, 82.) Hunter, 85, 87 Elias Ashmole, 20 August 1672, BL MS Sloane 3188, 2r-2v and Ashmole, 10 September 1672, BL MS Sloane 3188, 2v-3 in Elias Ashmole, 1617-1692: His Autobiographical and Historical Notes, His Correspondence, and Other Contemporary Sources Relating to His Life and Work, ed. C. H. Josten (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1966), 3:1264-65, 1270-71 (hereafter Autobiographical and Historical Notes) Ashmole, 20 August 1672, Bod MS Ashmole 1136, 47v; Ashmole, 10 September 1672, BL MS Sloane 3188, 2v-3; and Ashmole to Wood, 20 December 1672, Bod MS Wood F. 39, 59; in Autobiographical and Historical Notes, 3:1264, 1271, 1289. Ashmole, 29 January 1672, Bod MS Ashmole 1788, 158, in Autobiographical and Historical Notes, 3:1242-43. Gabriel Naudé Instructions Concerning Erecting a Library, trans. John Evelyn (London: Printed for G. Bedle, T. Collins . . . and J. Crook, 1661), 80-82 (quote on 81). ([David] McKitterick, Print, Manuscript and the Search for Order, 1450-1830 [Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2003], 12-15). William H. Sherman, Used Books: Marking Readers in Renaissance England (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2008), especially 7-10. (Naudé, Instructions, 81-82 [quote on 81]). Ashmole, "Copy of Elias Ashmore’s Will from the Registry of the Prerogative Court of Canterbury,” Bod MS Ashmole 1834, 62r. (Josten, in Autobiographical and Historical Notes, 2:671; 3:1117-18, 1240). Josten, Biographical Introduction, in Autobiographical and Historical Notes, 1:209-10; Ann Geneva, Astrology and the Seventeenth-Century Mind: William Lilly and the Language of the Stars (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1995). Lauren Kassell, Medicine and Magic in Elizabethan London: Simon Forman: Astrologer, Alchemist, and Physician (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2005). Stephen Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides, 1635-59, and the Pursuit of Scientific and Philosophical Manuscripts: The Religious Ethos of an Intelligencer," Seventeenth Century 6 (1991): 33-55. (Hartlib, Ephemerides, 1634, Sheffield University Library, Hartlib Papers, 50H, 29/2/53B-54A; quoted in Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 36). (Aubrey, "Brief Lives" Chiefly of Contemporaries, Set Down by John Aubrey, Between the Years 1669 and 1696, ed. Andrew Clark [Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1898], 36-37). (Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 46). Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 50-51 (Gerhardt, “‘No quyckar merchandyce than library bokes,’” 413). Wright, "The Dispersal of the Libraries in the Sixteenth Century," 170. Ibid., 175. John Bale, quoted in ibid., 153-54. "John Bale to Matthew Parker, 30 July 1560," in The Recovery of the Past in Early Elizabethan England: Documents by John Bale and John Joscelyn from the Circle of Matthew Parker, ed. Timothy Graham and Andrew G. Watson (Cambridge: Cambridge Bibliographical Society, 1998), 17; quoted in Gerhardt, “‘No Quyckar Merchandyce than Library Bokes,’” 409. (John Bale and John Leland, The Laboryouse Journey and Serche of Johan Leland [London: S. Mierdman for J. Bale, 1549], Giiir; quoted in Gerhardt, '"No Quyckar Merchandyce than Library Bokes,"' 421). (Autobiographical and Historical Notes, 1:184-86 and 3:1270-71; quote on 1271). (Aubrey, RS MS 92, 221). (Aubrey, An Idea of Education of Young Gentlemen (1683/84), Bod MS Aubrey 10, 65r). John Houghton, A Collection for the Improvement of Husbandry and Trade (London: n.p., 1692-1703), 13.356-59 (19 May-9 June 1699) Aubrey, RS MS 92, 221. Lhwyd, “Parochial Queries,” Bod MS Ashmole 1820, 143r. Lucien X. Polastron, Books on Fire: The Destruction of Libraries Throughout History, trans. Jon E. Graham (Rochester, Vt.: Inner Traditions, 2007). Lhwyd to Baxter, 7 September 1708, in Early Sciences in Oxford, ed. R. T. Gunther (Oxford: Printed for the subscribers, 1920-45), 14:545 (hereafter ESIO). Ibid. Peter Stallybrass, "Printing for Manuscript" (Rosenbach Lectures, University of Pennsylvania, February 2006). Aubrey, Idea of Education. An edition or the manuscript was prepared by J. E. Stephens as Aubrey on Education: A Hitherto Unpublished Manuscript by the Author of Brief Lives, ed. J. E. Stephens (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1972). [Michael Hunter] John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning, 50-55. (see Hunter, John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning, 50n.11). (Aubrey, Idea of Education, 2r). Michael Hunter's review in Journal of Educational Administration and History 6, no. 2 (1974): 61 Hunter, "How to Edit a Seventeenth-Century Manuscript," 286. Aubrey, Aubrey on Education, 97. (Aubrey, Aubrey on Education, 109). (Aubrey, Aubrey on Education, 111). Aubrey, Aubrey on Education, 129. Ibid., 125-26. Hunter, John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning, 52. Aubrey, "Collection of Grammaticall learning," Bod MS Aubrey 22, items 1 and 8. Aubrey, Idea of Education, 64-65. (Aubrey to Wood, 13 (January?) 1680/81, Bod MS Wood F.39, 351V). Hunter, John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning, 64-70. Walter Benjamin, "The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction," in Benjamin, Illuminations, ed. Hannah Arendt, trans. Harry Zohn (New York: Schocken Books, 1968), 217-52. Aubrey, Aubrey on Education, 97. Hunter, introduction, 7. Aubrey to Wood, 8 November 1692, Bod MS Wood F. 39, 437; quote in Anthony Powell, John Aubrey and His Friends (London: Hogarth Press, 1963), 219-20. Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 33-55. Elizabeth Yale, "Manuscript Technologies: Correspondence, Collaboration, and the Construction of Natural Knowledge in Early Modern Britain" (PhD diss., Harvard University, 2008), 61-64. (Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 40). Hartlib, Ephemerides, 1639, Hartlib Papers, 30/4/27B; quoted in Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 42. (Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 48-49). (Aubrey to Wood, n.d, MS Wood F.39, 318r). Adrian Johns, The Nature of the Book (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1998), 496-97. (Clucas, "Samuel Hartlib's Ephemerides," 45). Johns, Nature of the Book, 495. Ibid., 495-96. Lhwyd, Bod MS Ashmole 1820, 78V. Ibid., 77V. "Inquires for Barbary Recommended by the R. Society to the Favour and Care of His Excellency the Lord Henry Howard, his Majesties Ambassadour Extraordinary to the Emperour of Marocco," Royal Society Library, Register Book of the Royal Society 4 (1668-75): 53. Plot to Fell, c.1673, ESIO, 12:336. Ibid. (The Itinerary of John Leland the Antiquary [Oxford: Thomas Hearne, 1710-12]). James P. Carley, "Leland, John (c. 1503-1552)," Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2004-8); (ODNB) (Mendyk, "Speculum Britanniae," 45-46). Plot to Fell, c.1673, ESIO, 12:337. (Plot to Fell, c. 1673, ESIO, 12:335-36). Lhwyd to Lloyd, 23 November 1707, ESIO, 14: 536. Lhwyd to Thomas Tanner, {spring 1698}, ESIO, 14:370 Lhwyd to Thomas Tonkin, 16 March 1702/3, ESIO, 14: 485. Jürgen Habermas, The structural Transformation of the Public sphere: An Inquiry into a Category of Bourgeois Society, trans. Thomas Burger (Cambridge: MIT Press, 1991). Harold Mah, "Phantasies of the Public Sphere: Rethinking the Habermas of the Historians," Journal of Modern History 72 (2000): 153-82; Mark Knights, Representation and Misrepresentation in Later Stuart Britain: Partisanship and Political Culture (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2006), 48-53; Brian Cowan, The Social Life of Coffee: The Emergence of the British Coffeehouse (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005), 256. Hartlib and Gabriel Plattes, A Description of the Famous Kingdome of Macaria (London: Francis Constable, 1641) Hartlib, Considerations Tending to the Happy Accomplishment of Englands Reformation in Church and State (London: n.p., 1647) Hartlib, A Further Discovery of the Office of Publick Address for Accomodations (London: n.p., 1648). Yale, "Manuscript Technologies," 196-235. Charles Webster, The Great Instauration (London: Duckworth, 1975) James R. Jacob and Margaret C. Jacob, "The Anglican Origins of Modern Science: The Metaphysical Foundations of the Whig Constitution," Isis 71 (1980): 251-67. Philip, The Bodleian Library, 5-6 (Josten, Biographical Introduction, in Autobiographical and Historical Notes, 1:301). Martin Welch, "The Foundation of the Ashmolean Museum," in Tradescant's Rarities: Essays on the Foundation of the Ashmolean Museum in 1683, with a Catalogue of the Surviving Early Collections, ed. Arthur MacGregor (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1983), 40-58. Elias Ashmole, "Statutes, Orders, & Rules for the Ashmolean Museum in the University of Oxon," Bod MS Ashmole 1820, 296r-297V. (Oxford: E Theatro Sheldoniano, 1697). John Houghton, Collection for the Improvement of Husbandry and Trade. (Houghton, Collection, 5.105, 3 August 1694). Bernard, "De ratione & utilitate hujus catalogi epistola," in Catalogi manuscriptorum Angliae et Hiberniae, vol. 1. Edward Bernard, Librorum manuscriptorum academiarum Oxoniensis & Cantabrigiensis & celebrium per Angliam Hiberniamque Bibliothecarum Catalogus cum Indice Alphabetico (Oxford: n.p., 1694). (Bernard, Catalogi manuscriptorum Angliae et Hiberniae, 1:3). Kate Bennett, "Materials Towards a Critical Edition of John Aubrey's Brief Lives" (PhD diss., Oxford University, 1993), 23, 25. (Bacon, Works, ed. James Spedding [Boston: Taggard and Thompson, 1864], 8:423-24). Bennett, "Materials Towards a Critical Edition of John Aubrey's Brief Lives," 10, 25. Aubrey wrote, "This Collection of Grammaticall learning, and another in 80. is in relation to my Idea of the Education of the Noblesse" (Bod MS Aubrey 22, 1). (Aubrey, Idea of Education, 2r). (Aubrey to Evelyn, 10 May 1692, Idea of Education, 1ar). Kate Bennett, "John Aubrey's Collections and the Early Modern Museum," Bodleian Library Record, 17 (2001): 213-45. John Buchanan-Brown, "The Books Presented to the Royal Society by John Aubrey, FRS," Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London 28 (1974):167-93, especially 173-83. (Ray to Aubrey, 18 November 1691, Bod MS Aubrey 13, 175r). Lhwyd to Aubrey, 12 February {1690/91}, ESIO, 14:133. (Aubrey to Wood, 3 August 1689, MS Wood F. 40, 372). (Graham Parry, "Wood, Anthony a (1632-1695)," ODNB). Broadway, "No Historie so Meete," 95-100. (Aubrey to Wood, 11 September 1676, Bod MS Woof F.39, 3O2r).
